text.p: Australia's conservative government on Tuesday announced a boost in defence spending to give the military more firepower and increase its ability to fight overseas.
Treasurer Peter Costello, announcing the budget for the fiscal year from July, said defence spending would increase to A$10.4 billion from A$10.0 billion, a two percent real rise.
It is the second consecutive year that defence has been shielded from across-the-board cuts aimed at wiping out the government deficit, forecast at A$3.853 billion in 1997/98.
Savings from defence staff and administrative cuts -- up to A$1 billion (US$780 million) a year -- would also be used to buy more weapons and upgrade existing firepower and facilities.
"The defence of Australia's interests is a task that this government takes very seriously," Defence Minister Ian McLachlan said in a statement.
"The development and maintenance of a more efficient, effective and capable defence force is therefore a priority."
New measures announced in the budget include upgraded weaponry, sonar and countermeasure equipment for the ANZAC class frigates, purchase of maritime seabed mines and new communications.

Since winning office 14 months ago, the Liberal-National government has abandoned the previous Labor administration's policy of largely limiting defence to protection of Australia's coastline and air and sea approaches.
McLachlan said last month that Australia was prepared to send its forces anywhere in the world to defence Australian interests and could even intervene in internal disputes in other countries.
Canberra and Washington also last year agreed to boost their defence cooperation and ability to jointly fight offshore.
Spending on equipment and stores would increase about five percent in 1997/98, a one percent real boost, with A$2.3 billion to be spent buying and upgrading weapons and equipment, McLachlan said.

The money will be spent on ongoing programmes to buy new ANZAC class frigates, Collins class submarines, transport aircraft, long-distance radar and light armoured vehicles, upgrades for F-111 bombers and F/A 18 fighters and to fund an already announced restructuring of the army.
